My full-mouthed bags may now be filled with air,
The devil and ambition taught it me.

sp.speaker: Mavo.
sp.l: Is that Philarchus that complains? 'tis so,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: See how Mavortius turns away his face,
to seek to friends 'tis holden for disgrace.

sp.speaker: Mavo.
sp.l: Time was, I could have dined amongst my friends,
Now stands at every door a lack and apes
And tells me 'tis too late, his lord hath dined.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This miserable world would make one mad;
I stepped unto a vintner at the bar,
And offered him my rapier for a pawn;
The saucy slave took it in such a scorn,
And flung it in the streets, replying thus,
Mere want brings weapons out of use with us.

sp.speaker: Mavo.
sp.l: See poor Philarchus pouring out his plaints,
To unrelenting walls, relentless men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Are wounds rewards for soldiers in the field?
What? sell our lands, are these the fruits of war?
Then die Philarchus, let not shame survive,
Thy fainting honour, dead and yet alive.

sp.speaker: Mavo.
sp.l: Here come our wives, how wretchedly they look.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My jewels pawned, my rings are gone to wrack,
The greedy usurer hath gotten all.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: I am a prey to wretched poverty,
Ill featured famine will devour us up,
Whose wrinkled face, is like pale death's aspect.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Behold my wife like winter's parramour,
Robbed and bereaved of nuptial ornaments.
"Hide thee Philarchus lower then the grave,
" the earth will cover though it cannot save.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: If men lament, whose wonted iron-hearts,
Were harder than the armour they have worn,
And wail the agent of a woman's voice,
What shall weak women and poor ladies do?
Fall to those tears, that we were born unto.

sp.speaker: Mavo.
sp.l: Could I but learn (With Croesus) to endure
The falling sickness of sad poverty,
who lost a rich commanding empery
Patience would prove a tutor to my grieves.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Thou wants a Solon to consort with thee,
To prove affliction is the perfect way
That leads to Jove's tribunal dignity;
Ill haste thou governed thy prosperity,
That canst not smile in mere adversity.
Look upon me (The poorest slave in show,
That ever fortune buried in mishap:)
Yet this is nature's richest jewel-house
And teacheth me to weep at all your wants.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, thou art far more wretcheder than we,
How canst thou teach us then tranquillity?

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Seest thou this poor and naked bosom here?
Dost thou behold this scorned uncovered head?
When thou wast rich and peerless in thy pride,
Content did never harbour in thy breast,
Nor ere had love, her residence in thee,
(I mean the love of perfect happiness)
But skilless grudging from a haughty spirit
Did blind thy senses with a slender merit.
Whilst I (Poor man) not subject to such thought
Gave entertain to those sweet blessed babes,
Which sapience brought from wisdom's holy breast,
And thought me rich to have their company.
By nursing them in peace I shunned all sloth,
Nor yet did plenty make me prodigal:
Pride I abhorred and termed the beggar's shield:
Nor ever did base envy touch my heart.
Yet always loved to bear (As Solon said,)
A turtles eye within an aspics head:
Nor could the rattling fury of fierce war
Astonish me more than the midnight clock,
The trumpeter to contemplation:
For poverty, I shake her by the hand,
As welcome lady to this woeful land.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: How might we tread the paths to happy ends,
Since foes to learning are not virtues friends.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: First entertain submission in your souls
To frame true concord in one unity.
Behold the fair proportion of a man,
Whom heavens have created so complete,
Yet if the arm make war against the head,
Or that the heart rebel against the brain,
This elemental body (Thus compact,)
Is but a scattered chaos of revenge;
Your laws appointed to be positive,
(By war confounded) must be brought again.
For law is that which love and peace maintain.

sp.speaker: Phili.
sp.l: Thou son of knowledge (Richer than a man)
We censure thy advice as oracles.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Follow, and I'll instruct you what I can:

sp.speaker: Ma ▪
sp.l: We followed beasts before but now a man.

div.stage: Enter Fourcher; Vourcher, Lyon-rash, and velure.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.l: O heavens pouring high-prized savours forth,
Like to the honey dew that sweets the leaves,
Once send us peace, that fairest palm-crowned Queen.

sp.speaker: Vour.
sp.l: Ruin and war the precedents of wrath,
That cropped the fifty sons of Hecuba,
Have rid their circuit through this fertile soil,
And quite transformed it to a wilderness.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Come let us sit and mourn with sad laments,
The heavy burdens of our discontents.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: To wail our want let speaking slack the pain,
For words of grief divide the grief in twain.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: Our shops (Sometimes) were stuffed with cloth of gold,
But war hath emptied them, and spiders build
Their cob-web-tents; weaving foul dusty lawn
For poor woe-working poverty to wear.

sp.speaker: Four.
sp.l: O woes! behold our poor distressed wives.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: From poverty to famine, worse and worse

sp.speaker: Fili.
sp.l: The scourge of pride, and heaven's detested curse.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: Where's that excess consumed upon the back?

sp.speaker: Fili.
sp.l: Sunk down to hell whilst hunger feels the lack.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: Who now will pity us, that scorned the poor?

sp.speaker: Fili.
sp.l: Pity is passed when peace is out of door.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: Drink thou my tears and I will drink up thine,
For naught but tears is misery's salt wine.

sp.speaker: Fill.
sp.l: We that have scorned to dress our meat ourselves,
Now would be glad if we had meat to dress.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: And if lament were remedy for want
Their cates wear course that in lament were scant,

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Comfort sweet wife, ill lasts not always so:
And good (Sometimes) makes end of lingering woe.

sp.speaker: Perp.
sp.l: My grief is thine,

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: And mine is most for thee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My care is thine.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Be mine for thee and me.
Faith poverty hath paid my wife on the petticoat.
From these devouring worms, eat men alive,
And swallow up whole manors at a bit
The whilst our hungry bodies die for lack,
And honest husbandry must go to wrack.
Pray sirs for peace, that best may please us all.
From city's pride the country takes his fall.
'Tis time, for ploughshares (Now) are turned to bills,
Carthorses pressed to carry cavaliers,
True labouring servants counted soldiers slaves,
Though famine hungerstarve yet heaven saves.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Then let us pray to heaven all for peace.
For thence comes comfort, plenty and increase.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Post me no posting; pay me the shot,
Ye live by wit; but we must live by money.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Goody sharp, be not so short,
I'll pay you, when I give you money.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: When you give me money? go to, I'll bear no longer.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: What and be under fifty?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Master Constable ho, these players will not pay their shot.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Faith sir, war hath so pinched us we must pawn.

sp.speaker: Cun,
sp.l: Alas poor players: hostis; what comes it to?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The sharers dinners six pence a piece, the hirelings pence.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.p: What sixpence an egg, and two and two at an egg.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Faith famine affords no more.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.p: Fellows bring out the hamper choose somewhat out o'th stock.
sp.l: What will you have this cloak to pawn,
What think you it's worth?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Some four groats,

sp.speaker: Own
sp.l: The pox is in this age, here's a brave world fellows.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: You may see what it is to laugh at the audience.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well it shall serve for a pawn.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Soft sirs I must talk with you for tax money,
To relieve the poor, not a penny paid yet,

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Sir, (At few words we shared but xu. pence last week.

sp.speaker: Cun ▪
sp.l: But 'tis well known, that each maintains his punk,
And taverns it with drunken suppers still.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Alas they are our wives.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ye are not all married.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Who are not are glad to bring such as they can get.

sp.speaker: Bels.
sp.l: Before I'll give such a precedent, I'll leave playing.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Faith and I too: I'll rather fall to work.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Fall to work after playing unpossible.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sirs, will you here the truth.

sp.speaker: Gut.
sp.l: Sir you may choose,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: But you must all choose
Whither you'll be shipped and set ashore no man
Knows where as the Romans did:
Or play for the maintenance of the poor;
And yourselves kept like honest men.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We choose neither.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Saving your sad tale, will you take a pot or two.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The dearth of malt denies it

sp.speaker: Clou.
sp.l: It's a hard world if the constable despise it.

sp.speaker: Guls,
sp.l: Must we be shipped in earnest,
Or do you make us sheep in jest,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ecce signum.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Constable do you know what you do.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ay, banish idle fellows out o'th' land,

sp.speaker: Bels.
sp.l: Why constable do you know what you see.

sp.speaker: Cun,
sp.l: Ay, I see a Madge owlet: and she sees not see.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: Know you our credit with sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: True, but your boasting hath cracked it, (I fear.)

sp.speaker: Gut.
sp.l: Faith I must fall to making fiddle strings again.

sp.speaker: Bles.
sp.l: And I to curl horse tails to make fools beards.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.l: I'll boldy fall to ballading again.

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.l: Sirs, those provisoes will not serve the turn,
What ho, sailors, ship away these players.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The wind blows fair, and we are ready sir.

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.l: No matter where it blows; away with them.

sp.speaker: Post-haste
sp.p: It's an ill wind blows a man thus clean out of ballading.

div.stage: Enter peace, Bacchus, Ceres, and plenty, bearing the cornu copiae, at the one door: at the other poverty, with her attendants; who beholding peace approach, vanish.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: Bondage, wan sickness, and bare poverty,
Vanish like clouds before the Eastern light,
Now peace appears, hence all to endless night,
And you dejected spirits, crushed with want,
Mount up your minds unto the fairest hope,
Need hath nursed peace within your horoscope,
The warm reflection of whose cheering beams,
Makes you as rich as bright Pactolus streams.
Shine plenteous bounty, crown the naked world,
With odourous wreaths of thy abundant sweets,
Laborious artisans, now bustle up,
Your drooping spirits with alacrity.
Peace gives your toiling sweat a due regard,
Crowning your labour with a rich reward.
Ceres be lavish, Bacchus swell to brim,
And all to peace sing a propitious hymn,

div.stage: They begin to sing, and presently cease.

lg.head: A song,
lg.l: With laurel shall our altars flame,
In honour of thy sacred name.

div.stage: Enter Astraea ushered by fame, supported by fortitude and religion, followed by virginity and artes.

sp.speaker: Peace.
sp.l: No more:
Be dumb in hushed observance at this sight,
Here comes amazements object, wonders height,
Peace's patroness, heaven's miracle,
Virtue's honour, earth's admiration,
Chastities crown, justice perfection,
Whose train is unpollute virginity,
Whose diadem of bright immortal fame,
Is burnished with valued respect,
Ineffable wonder of remotest lands;
Still sway thy gracious sceptre, I resign;
What I am is by thee, myself am thine,

sp.speaker: Q. eliza.
sp.l: Astraea mounts unto the throne.
Mount empress, whose praise for peace shall mount,
Whose glory, which thy solid virtues won,
Shall honour Europe whilst there shines a sun.
Crowned with heaven's inward beauties, world's applause,
Throned and reposed within the loving fear
Of thy adoring subjects: live as long
As time hath life, and fame a worthy tongue.
Still breath our glory, the world's empress,
Religion's guardian, peace's patroness;
Now flourish arts, the Queen of peace doth reign,
Virtue triumph, now she doth sway the stem,
Who gives to virtue, honour's diadem.
All sing paeans to her sacred worth,
Which none but angels tongues can warble forth:
Yet sing, for though we cannot light the sun,
Yet utmost might hath kind acceptance won.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Religion, arts, and merchandise, triumph, triumph:
Astraea rules, whose gracious eyes, triumph, triumph.
O'er vice's conquest, whose desires, triumph, triumph:
Whose all to chiefest good aspires, than all triumph.

div.stage:
In the end of the play.
Plenty,
Pride,
Envy,
War, and
Poverty.to enter and resign their several sceptres to peace, sitting in majesty.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
